title: How to Choose Cheese for Your Homemade Pizza

steps.headline: Don’t buy pre-shredded mozzarella.
steps.description: Instead, buy mozzarella in a block from your grocery’s deli. Then, shred the mozzarella at home. Using shredded deli mozzarella will provide a creamier and richer cheese flavor. If you are making a thirteen inch pizza, then ask for a four to six ounce block of cheese. If your pizza is smaller, then ask for less cheese.

steps.headline: Choose between whole or skim milk varieties.
steps.description: Whole milk mozzarella has a creamier texture (similar to cream cheese) and has more flavor than skim milk varieties. The creamier texture and better flavor is due to the higher fat content. However, it has only one to two more grams of fat per serving than skim milk mozzarella. Because whole milk mozzarella has a richer flavor, you do not need to use as much cheese if you were using skim milk mozzarella.

steps.headline: Try fresh mozzarella.
steps.description: This version of mozzarella is the classic Italian cheese for pizzas. Fresh mozzarella is sold in eight-ounce balls. It is usually vacuum-sealed in a container sitting in whey. Because this cheese is soft and breaks apart easily, it cannot be shredded. When using this cheese on your pizza, slice it up and place the pieces spaced apart on the pizza. The mozzarella will melt and spread out over the pizza. You can find fresh mozzarella at your grocery store’s deli. Fresh mozzarella has a short shelf life and should be used within a week once it is opened.

steps.headline: Choose a provolone.
steps.description: Provolone is a great cheese to combine with mozzarella on your pizza. Like the mozzarella, purchase a block of provolone from the deli and shred it at home. For added flavor, choose an aged or Italian provolone cheese. The ratio of provolone to mozzarella depends on your tastes. If you are unsure, begin with 70 percent mozzarella and 30 percent provolone.

steps.headline: Opt for a semi-firm cheese.
steps.description: Semi-firm cheeses like Gouda, Gruyere, fontina, emmental, and Edam also taste great when mixed with mozzarella. This variety of cheese has a thick, creamy texture when melted. Dice up these cheeses and place the pieces on your pizza. Gouda goes well with caramelized onions, bacon, or roasted vegetables. Mix one part Gouda to four parts mozzarella.

steps.headline: Try a hard cheese.
steps.description: Hard cheeses like Parmesan cheese, grana padano, and pecorino romano (romano) are great finishing touches on pizzas. Hard cheeses are rich in flavor, so grate or shave them over your finished pizza. Parmigiano reggiano has a richer, more intense flavor than American made Parmesan cheese.

steps.headline: Consider cream cheese.
steps.description: Cream cheeses like regular cream cheese, mascarpone, boursin, and goat cheese are great alternatives to mozzarella. Scatter small chunks over the dough. Place the pieces on the bottom under the sauce and toppings since it burns easily. Try infused cream cheese for extra flavor, for example, garlic, rosemary, or basil-infused cream cheeses.

steps.headline: Use cold cheese.
steps.description: To prevent your cheese from overcooking, make sure the cheese is cold before placing it on the pizza. If not, the cheese might burn. Also, try not to use too much cheese. The proper amount of cheese for a thirteen inch pizza is four to six ounces.

steps.headline: Avoid some cheeses.
steps.description: Oily or processed cheeses should be avoided. These include cheeses like Velveeta, cheddar, and pre-shredded cheese. For the best flavor and results, buy a block of cheese from the deli and shred it at home yourself.

steps.headline: Add hard cheeses later.
steps.description: Hard cheeses like Parmesan, grana padano, and romano are very dry and delicate. If you put them on the pizza before it goes into the oven, they will burn and lose their flavor. Therefore, put these cheeses on the pizza only after it has come out of the oven.

steps.headline: Shred your cheese.
steps.description: You can use a hand grater, rotary cheese grater, or a food processor with a shredding attachment to shred your cheese. Place soft cheeses in the freezer an hour before you begin grating it. This will make grating soft cheeses much easier. You can purchase a cheese grater from your local grocery or home goods store, or from a discount retailer like Target and Wal-Mart.
